{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3140732,"name":"New Mentor Treading Water","username":"New_Mentor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/e5b9ba/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-06T19:02:06.479Z","cooked":"

Hello a new mentor here. My team has a mechanism that turns about 270 degrees and has a mechanical stop. The mechanism is activated by a neo 550. A questions i have is

The mechanical safety stop will protect the arm from not moving past the 270 degree mark… and we use the encoder to see how much have we turned. I am worried that due to brownouts or bugs the motor may not stop and we may stall the motor … so, is it a good idea to wire a limit switch to the Sparkmax to limit the fwd movement when the limit switch is closed by the mechanism. This way we have a mechanical stop to protect the robot from damage, encoder to stop motor and a limit switch wired to sparkmax data port just in case roborio enters brownouts or bugs etc…and if i understood the documentation from spark max right i dont need any code to use a limit switch wired to a sparkmax… thoughts

Thanks
NM

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-02-06T19:02:06.479Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":506,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":2586.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":425947,"topic_slug":"using-limit-switch-as-motor-safety","display_username":"New Mentor Treading Water","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57078,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/using-limit-switch-as-motor-safety/425947/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3140748,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-06T19:17:00.407Z","cooked":"
New_Mentor:

Hello a new mentor here

Welcome!

What you suggest is common practice.

A question you will have to resolve is whether you make the limit switch normally-open (NO) or normally-closed (NC). In my experience, the most common physical failure in (the wiring of) a limit switch is a break, making the circuit always open. (The alternative short, making the circuit always closed, is rare.)

If you wire the limit switch NO, and the wire breaks, you won’t discover the problem until the motor is stalling against the hard stop, possibly damaging the robot.

If you wire the limit switch NC, and the wire breaks, then that component of the robot will be inoperable for the rest of the match, even for uses where it would have been safe.

I cover this material in training every year, and someone once suggested wiring the switch up both ways so that you can detect a failure. This sounds interesting, but I have never seen it done, and the Spark MAX, of course, only accepts one limit switch per direction.

Note that, in addition to having the Spark MAX check the limit switch directly, you can also check it in code. This might be useful if you want to, say, reset the offset on a relative encoder or display the limit switch on the Smart Dashboard.

If you’re concerned about stalling, you may want to look into current limiting.

bovlb:

both ways

One of them would have to be brought back to the roboRIO or another relay.

A little “light” reading for the off-season door safety circuits that shows some interlocks. They even consider the switch contacts welding together. Maybe a search would find better references for moving objects and not doors. Your guidance is good for us.

In industry something like an over-travel limit switch would be done as Normally Closed for the very reason you listed about wire breakage. Better to be safe and have the machine stop due to a wire break rather than destroy an expensive machine.

I ask my team to use the encoder feedback for normal operation, followed by end of travel limit switches (for unexpected situations) and ultimately a physical hard stop.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

One of them would have to be brought back to the roboRIO or another relay.

I think both of them. I would hesitate to wire the common line on a single limit switch to both the Spark MAX and the RoboRIO, even if the other lines were theoretically never connected at the same time. Maybe you’re thinking of a double pole switch.
